Transfers from the bulk storage tank to the production system occur inside fixed steel pipes.  No hoses are utilized in the operation.  Needle valves are used to control the rate of flow into the mixers.

With elevated temperatures that occur during mid-to-late summer, the ammonia gas inside the bulk storage tank can expand, and possibly cause the relief valve to open in order to equalize the pressure inside the tank.  The relief valve will reseal itself when pressure is relieved.  These events are very short in duration - a few seconds at the most.

A complete failure or burst tank is highly unlikely.  The bulk storage tank was built under strict guidelines established in the ASME pressure vessel code.  The bulk anhydrous ammonia storage tank is protected by concrete traffic barriers.  All welding and structural work done on the tank or appendages are performed by certified welders.  



Explanation of How Hazard Releases are Prevented

Passive mitigation refers to equipment, devices, or technologies that function without human, mechanical or other energy input.  The passive mitigation systems in place at the Upper Sandusky facility are:
1.	Bulkhead breakaway unit located on the connection point to the storage tank anchors the ammonia plumbing into the ground. If a truck driver were to drive off without disconnecting from the bulkhead piping, the hose would break at the outside of the connection point.  An excess flow valve, just to the inside of the breakaway would prevent the delivery truck tank from emptying to the atmosphere.  Storage tank excess flow valves are installed at the tank openings.

Active mitigation refers to equipment, devices or technologies that require human, mechanical or other energy input to funct

ion.  The active mitigation systems in place at the Upper Sandusky facility are:
1.	Excess flow valves are located on all outgoing liquid and vapor valves on the storage tank.  These valves close automatically if the volume of gas or liquid flowing through the line exceeds the normal flow rate.  They won't reopen until the downstream shutoff valve is closed and the pressure equalizes on both sides of the valve seat.  Two principal causes of the excess valve closing are a ruptured hose or a broken pipe or shutoff valve downstream that is opened too quickly.
2.	Back check valves are located on the unloading lines of delivery trucks and are designed to ensure that the flow goes in one direction only.  This prevents anhydrous ammonia from flowing to a transport tank from the storage tank.  These valves are installed at the receiving manifold and are integral to the site flow indicator on the liquid fill line at the manifold. Back check valves are also installed at each mixer to prevent mixer products from entering the NH3 lines.
3.	Pressure-relief valves are located on the top of the bulk storage tank and fixed steel to relieve pressure that is too great.  This can be caused by elevated temperatures in the summer or overfilling.  They open directly to the atmosphere at 250 psig and close when the pressure inside the tank drops below this pressure.
4.	Mixer automation interlocks are installed at mixers 6 and 7.  Receiving manifold - integral to the site flow indicator on the liquid fill line at the manifold. Back check valves are also installed at each mixer to prevent mixer products from entering the NH3 lines.
5.	Failsafe valve closures are installed on mixers 6 and 7.  If there is a loss of compressed air the valves on the ammonia lines of mixers 1 and 2 will return to the close position if they happened to be open.
6.	Air collection units are installed at mixers 1, 2, 6 and 7.  These units have fans on them to draw any dust and vapors that form in the mixers in

to a collection unit that uses water to sequester them.
7.	A pneumatic emergency shutoff system activates any of four emergency shutoff valves (snappy joes).  This stops the flow of ammonia by remote activation of a spring loaded valve.

Prevention Program
Preventive maintenance is an integral piece of this facility's hazard management program.  All system components are visually inspected at least monthly, and usually daily during the production season.  A good PM program is our strongest defense against a release of anhydrous ammonia.  Records of all maintenance tasks performed on the tank or appendages are also on file.

This facility uses third party contractors for all maintenance, welding and construction performed on the tank.  Copies of all reports are on file. The facility undergoes a complete ammonia inspection by a third party at least every five years.

See Steps Taken to Address Hazards for more information on prevention measures and identification.

Management System
(see Steps Taken to Address Hazards)

Equipment maintenance
All equipment maintenance is formally documented. See the Prevention Program section for further explanation.

Training
All employees receive annual training on anhydrous ammonia, emergency action plan and spill procedures, and hazard communication.  Documentation and attendance rosters are on file at the facility.  

Contractors
All contractors receive a contractor safety review prior to performing work at the facility.  During this review, they are informed of any potential hazards at the facility, emergency procedures, site-specific safety rules and the ability to request an SDS for any product at any time.  Contractor safety performance is also reviewed annually.  Safety performance records are retained in a Lotus Notes database.

Upper Sandusky Facility
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

Source and Product Description

The Upper Sandusky facility is located in Crane Township, Wyandot County. The facility sets on the south side of County Hwy 49, between SR 199 and US Route 30.  The facility is bordered by railroad tracks to the west, a farm field to the south, wooded lot to the east and a vacant parking lot (owned by The Andersons) to the north.  There are no residences within a ¼ mile of this facility.  

Facility operations include the manufacturing and distribution of wholesale of agricultural and industrial products.  Products are manufactured on site and then sold in bulk quantities, as well as 2½ gallon containers and 50 or 55 lb bags. The plant employs 40 full time workers and normal operating hours are 8:00 am to 5:00 p.m. five days a week, however there are second and third shifts for production.

Site management names and emergency contact information are posted on a sign at the entrance.


The only RMP regulated material at this facility is anhydrous ammonia.  A 12,000 gallon tank is used for bulk storage of  the material. When filled to the maximum 85% capacity, this tank can hold 10,200 gallons of anhydrous ammonia.  This material is a gas at ambient temperature and pressure.  It is a liquid when stored under pressure inside the tank.

Anhydrous ammonia is not a poison, but it is an inhalation / respiratory hazard.  Ammonia is a toxic material but it has no cumulative toxic effects on the human body.  However, it is acutely corrosive when it comes in contact with mucous membranes, in particular.  Anhydrous ammonia is a non-flammable gas under most conditions.

Summary of Major Hazards
The principal causes of ammonia emergencies are ruptured hoses and defective valves. The most probable time for an exposure or release to occur will be during a transfer from a delivery unit (generally a tanker truck) to the bulk storage tank.  Flexible h

ent audits at the facility.  The audits include a physical walk through of the entire facility and a review of all EPA, OSHA and DOT paperwork and training documentation.  Action items are noted and recommendations are made. The audits consist of five major topical areas:  Safety & Health, Environmental, Fire Protection & Security, Administrative and Housekeeping & Storage.  Issues are documented in a report and sent to the facility manager and upper management.  Updates on action item status must be made regularly.

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) has been completed at the Upper Sandusky facility, as part of their Process Safety Management program.  The analysis will be updated every five years, or as changes in the process are made.  PHA's are performed using the HazOp technique and analyze all aspects involved in the receiving, storage and utilization of anhydrous ammonia.  The evaluation team includes representatives from the corporate Safety Department, location management and operations employees.

Each operating parameter is discussed and evaluated.  Unless otherwise noted, situations are evaluated under the assumption that safety controls are in effect.  Potential consequences are listed and given a rating of 1 - 4 for severity and likelihood; with 1 being the worst case and 4 being none or very low.  When plotted, a risk value is assigned from A - D; with A being the worst and most critical item and D being of least consequence.  Results are evaluated and prioritized.

Formal investigations are performed for all ammonia related environmental or safety incidents.  Documentation is retained in a database.

A formal Management of Change (MOC) system is administered by the Safety Department.  An electronic MOC form is filled out whenever a major, minor or replacement in kind change is made to the ammonia system.  The MOC's are routed from the facility operator to the Engineering and Safety Departments for review and remarks.  Completed MOC doc

uments are stored in a Lotus Notes database.

Monthly Safety Committee meetings allow employees to discuss any concerns they may have with the operation of the facility.  Issues are documented and assigned to employees for follow-up. Records of all meetings are kept at the facility.


Response Action in the Event of a Release
In the event of a burst hose or defective valve, employees are instructed to shut down the system using the e-stop buttons that are strategically placed around the mixers and receiving/storage areas.

For an uncontainable release, employees will immediately call the police and fire department or other first responders, as appropriate.  All employees, customers and contractors are to be evacuated to an upwind location. Once the response team has arrived, we will work in concert with them to address the situation.  

The employees are instructed to make emergency phone calls in this order:  911 and then the facility manager.  The facility manager will notify the corporate Safety Department, who will then make all the necessary state agency notifications. All emergency contact names and numbers are found in the facility Emergency Action Plan, which is reviewed and updated annually.

Communication procedures with responders 
The local city Fire Department is invited to tour this facility at least once a year.  During these tours, we explain each of the processes at the plant and where hazardous materials are stored and used.  The Fire Department is informed on our limited response capabilities and expectation in the event of an ammonia release. The Fire Department is instructed on the location of all emergency shutoff valves and on-site response equipment.  We believe that a strong relationship with first responders is our best defense.

Release History
The facility has not had a release within the last five years.

The LEPC and state regulatory agencies receive a copy of our hazardous materials storage information, by March 1 eve
ry year, in accordance with our community right to know obligations.  A copy of the Upper Sandusky Emergency Action Plan is on file with the LEPC and the local fire departments.
